messages.content:
### Significance

Sickle cell disease (SCD) remains a major public health burden, affecting approximately 100,000 individuals in the United States. Current therapeutic options are limited to chronic blood transfusions, hydroxyurea, and the only potentially curative approach—bone‑marrow transplantation— which is restricted by donor availability and significant morbidity. A one‑time, gene‑editing therapy that directly corrects the sickle mutation in patient‑derived hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) could transform the treatment landscape, offering a permanent cure without the need for lifelong immunosuppression. This project aligns with NIH’s strategic priority to develop innovative gene‑based therapies for hemoglobinopathies.

### Innovation

We propose to employ a newly engineered CRISPR‑Cas9 variant (eSpCas9‑v2) that exhibits markedly reduced off‑target cleavage while maintaining high on‑target efficiency. Unlike conventional viral delivery methods, our approach utilizes non‑viral electroporation to introduce the ribonucleoprotein complex into HSCs, minimizing insertional mutagenesis risks. This combination of a high‑fidelity nuclease with a safe, scalable delivery platform represents a breakthrough in ex vivo gene therapy for hematologic disorders.

### Approach

**Aim 1: Optimize electroporation parameters for HSC transfection.** We will test a matrix of voltage, pulse length, and cell density conditions to maximize cell viability and editing efficiency.

**Aim 2: Assess on‑target editing efficiency in patient‑derived HSCs.** Using droplet digital PCR and next‑generation sequencing, we will quantify the proportion of alleles corrected at the β‑globin locus and evaluate off‑target activity.

**Aim 3: Perform pre‑clinical efficacy studies in a murine SCD model.** Edited HSCs will be transplanted into NSG‑SCD mice. Engraftment, hemoglobin correction, and disease phenotype rescue will be assessed over a 6‑month period.

Milestones and decision points are defined for each aim, with contingency plans for sub‑optimal outcomes.

#### Letter of Support – Dr. Alice Nguyen (University of Washington)

[University Letterhead]

Date: December 7, 2025

To the Review Committee:

I am delighted to support Dr. Elena Rossi’s NIH R01 application titled “CRISPR‑based Gene Therapy for Sickle Cell Disease.” My laboratory has a longstanding collection of patient‑derived hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) from individuals with sickle cell disease, and we are prepared to provide these primary cells for Dr. Rossi’s Aim 2 studies. Additionally, our expertise in hematopoietic differentiation and functional assays will be instrumental in validating the edited HSCs.

I commit to allocating laboratory space, consumables, and personnel time to ensure the success of this collaboration. I look forward to co‑authoring manuscripts arising from this work.

Sincerely,

Dr. Alice Nguyen, Ph.D.
Professor of Hematology
University of Washington
Email: aian@example.edu

#### Letter of Support – Dr. Marco Silva (Harvard Medical School)

[Harvard Medical School Letterhead]

Date: December 7, 2025

To the Review Committee:

I wholeheartedly endorse Dr. Elena Rossi’s proposal for a CRISPR‑based cure for sickle cell disease. Our laboratory has engineered the eSpCas9‑v2 variant used in this project and can supply sufficient purified protein and guide RNAs for all planned experiments. We will also provide technical assistance to optimize the electroporation protocol and verify on‑target specificity using our high‑throughput off‑target detection platform.

Our commitment includes dedicated bench time, reagents, and expertise throughout the three‑year project period. We anticipate significant scientific synergy and joint publications.

Best regards,

Dr. Marco Silva, Ph.D.
Associate Professor of Molecular Genetics
Harvard Medical School
Email: msilva@hms.harvard.edu

#### Letter of Support – Dr. Priya Patel (Stanford University)

[Stanford University Letterhead]

Date: December 7, 2025

To the Review Committee:

I am pleased to provide support for Dr. Elena Rossi’s R01 application focused on CRISPR‑mediated gene therapy for sickle cell disease. My laboratory will oversee all animal studies, including the transplantation of edited HSCs into the NSG‑SCD mouse model and subsequent phenotypic analyses. We will ensure full compliance with Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC) regulations and provide statistical expertise for data interpretation.

We are committed to allocating animal facility space, veterinary support, and personnel for the duration of the project. Collaborative manuscript preparation and data sharing will be integral to this partnership.

Sincerely,

Dr. Priya Patel, M.D., Ph.D.
Professor of Translational Medicine
Stanford University
Email: ppatel@stanford.edu
All sections and letters of support have been drafted. I will now assemble the complete proposal document in PDF format.
